title: SECTION B -SUPPLIES OR SERVICES AND PRICES/COSTS

subsections.title: B.1 GENERAL
subsections.content: The work shall be performed in accordance with all sections of this TOR and the contractor’s MAS contract, under which the resulting TO will be placed. A TO will be established for a period of up to five years (base period and four one-year option periods).

subsections.title: B.2 ORDER TYPES
subsections.content: The contractor shall perform the effort required by this TO on a firm-fixed price (FFP) basis for all awarded CLINs. There are four Option Periods of the same FFP contract type that may be exercised by the Government unilaterally under FAR 52.217-9 Option to Extend the Term of the Contract (Mar 2000), per the Services and Price Schedule found in section B.3 below.

subsections.title: B.3 SERVICES AND PRICES/COSTS
subsections.content:
All labor categories proposed and used on this task order must be labor categories awarded on the firm’s MAS contract, and the SaaS proposed must also be awarded on the firm’s MAS contract. As stated below in Section L, the quote must state the SINs applicable to the awarded labor categories and the awarded SaaS. The Government considers the following SINs to be within scope of either the labor categories or SaaS: SIN 518210C (Cloud Computing and Cloud Related IT Professional Services) SIN 54151 (Software Maintenance Services) SIN 54151S (Information Technology Professional Services) SIN 54151ECOM (Electronic Commerce and Subscription Services) SIN 511210 (Software Licenses) Any labor categories or SaaS awarded under other SINs are considered out of scope. Each POP will include one FFP CLIN for the software license as well as one FFP CLIN for all services that do not come with the software license. The quote will clearly state what is included in the price of the software license. All other requirements to be met by proposed labor categories will go into a second FFP CLIN. The Base Period is to include all implementation and setup costs. See Section L for instructions on the pricing quote. The SaaS will be quoted based on an annual price or a monthly price, depending on how it is awarded and priced on the MAS contract. The quote will clearly state whether the price proposed is an annual price or a monthly price. The Government is seeking discounts on the TO from the awarded prices on the MAS contract. subsections.title: C.1 BACKGROUND
subsections.content:
The NBRC is a Federal-State partnership for economic and community development in Maine, pmNew Hampshire, Vermont, and New York. Each year, the NBRC provides Federal funds for critical economic and community development projects throughout the northeastern United States. The NBRC has grown rapidly over the past four Fiscal Years, from $20MM in appropriations in Fiscal Year (FY) 18 to over $60MM in FY 22, including partnership programs administered through collaborating agencies. Additionally, the NBRC was appropriated $150MM as part of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Legislation (BIL), to be deployed over the next five fiscal years. 
The NBRC is seeking to migrate to a modern, secure SaaS GMS to not only facilitate compliance with government regulations and statutes, but to transform the way the agency executes its mission. The NBRC seeks a system that can serve as a portal for multiple grant application cycles / year and facilitate management and oversight of grant-funded projects, up to and including close-out activities. 
Given the growth identified above, the NBRC anticipates receiving approximately 200 – 400 project proposals per year, awarding up to 75-85 new awards per year, totaling approximately $50MM per year, at least through FY 28 (including both the IIJA funds referenced earlier, in addition to regular, annual appropriations). There are roughly 10 intake forms per project during the application process. The NBRC anticipates that approximately 12-15 staff, approximately 20-25 external reviewers, and up to 300 applicants and current grantees will need to use the new system annually. We anticipate these users would access the system through the established GUI created for the GMS. The NBRC thus seeks a grants management and reporting system that increases effectiveness, efficiency, and accountability and will allow automated processing and oversight of the grant’s workflow for each of their programs. 
The steps involved in the current approval/rejection process of a grant application are as follows: 
● 
Applications are reviewed for eligibility, if they are ineligible, they are marked as such and the applicant is informed. 
● 
If the application is eligible it is marked as such then continues to a review process to determine its rank among the projects in each state. 
● 
After review and ranking it is voted on by the NBRC and if selected, awarded and turns into a grant through to completion and closeout. Emails generated during this process are NBRC staff-generated responses. 
The new GMS SaaS will streamline and address gaps in business processes, grants management, financial interfaces [(the NBRC currently uses Pegasys Financial Services (PFS) as its Federal Shared Service Provider (FSSP)], and data management. 
The new GMS SaaS will need to support the grant related business areas for the NBRC’s three two major grant programs, with the ability to accommodate future programmatic growth. The NBRC defines a "grant program" as a publicly accessible opportunity to deploy Federal dollars consistent with the NBRC's statute, clustered around authorized areas of funding as specified in 40 U.S.C., Subtitle V. The NBRC currently offers two such programs; one larger program called Catalyst and one smaller program called Forest Economy Program (FEP). Both programs are similar with regard to application content and requirements (e.g., submission of Federal form SF424a), with differences primarily focused on categories of the economy that the grant dollars are intended to support (e.g., the "forest products industry"). While the NBRC cannot predict with 100% accuracy whether new programs will be added in future years -because Congress can appropriate funds for a specific program at any time -we do not anticipate more than two new programs being added in the next 2-3 years.

subsections.title: C.1.1 PURPOSE
subsections.content:
The purpose of this requirement is to acquire a SaaS application that is configurable to the NBRC’s requirements and specifications contained in this PWS. 
This is a non-personal services contract to provide grants management SaaS. The Government shall not exercise any supervision or control over the contract service providers performing the services herein. Such contract service providers shall be accountable solely to the vendor who, in turn is responsible to the Government. 
The vendor shall provide a cloud based application, i.e., SaaS, as defined by NIST SP 800-145. The NIST definition of SaaS reads, in part… 
“The applications are accessible from various client devices through either a thin client interface, such as a web browser (e.g., web-based email), or a program interface. The consumer does not manage or control the underlying cloud infrastructure including network, servers, operating systems, storage, or even individual application capabilities, with the possible exception of limited user specific application configuration settings.” (NIST SP 800-145) 
The SaaS application will perform grants management administrations defined in this Performance Work Statement (PWS).The vendor shall perform to the standards referenced in this PWS. 
The Government is not requiring the contractor to import historical grant data. However, it is possible the Government may request an import in the future via a modification. The Government will import approximately 50 .CSV data folders/files, approximately 12,000 KB in size.

subsections.title: C.1.2 AGENCY MISSION
subsections.content:
The mission of the NBRC is to catalyze regional, collaborative, and transformative community economic development approaches that alleviate economic distress and position the region for economic growth. 
For more information on the NBRC, visit the website at https://www.nbrc.gov/

subsections.title: C.2 SCOPE
subsections.content: The major deliverable to be provided under this PWS is a Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) GMS SaaS application that meets all requirements detailed in this PWS for improved administration of applications and awards and improved internal control structures for data collection and data management processes.

subsections.title: C.3 CURRENT INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY (IT)/NETWORK ENVIRONMENT
C.4 OBJECTIVE
subsections.content:
The NBRC is seeking a new, cloud-hosted GMS SaaS application in compliance with the Office of Management and Budget, OMB Memorandum 19-16, the Grants Quality Service Management Office (QSMO), which provided standards of practice for grants management systems. The NBRC will follow the Federal Integrated Business Framework (FIBF) (reference Appendix A: Federal Integrated Business Framework Grants Management Business Lifecycle) in this SaaS implementation. The product must, at a minimum, align with the Grants Management Business Standard Components, including the Federal Business Lifecycle, Business Capabilities, and Standard Data Elements. The SaaS application must receive and provide data in conformance with federal government specified data element definitions in compliance with the FIBF and 2 CFR Subtitle A. In addition, the product shall meet Section 508 accessibility requirements. 
The vendor shall provide a cloud based application, i.e., SaaS, as defined by NIST SP 800-145.The NIST definition of SaaS reads, in part… 
“The applications are accessible from various client devices through either a thin client interface, such as a web browser (e.g., web-based email), or a program interface. The consumer does not manage or control the underlying cloud 
infrastructure including network, servers, operating systems, storage, or even individual application capabilities, with the possible exception of limited user specific application configuration settings.” (NIST SP 800-145) 
The SaaS application will perform grants management administrations defined in this Performance Work Statement (PWS).The vendor shall perform to the standards referenced in this PWS.

subsections.title: C.5 TASKS
subsections.content:
The vendor shall offer a SaaS grants management solution that: 
● 
Will enable NBRC staff to support and streamline the grants management business process as a whole, and to monitor, evaluate, and report on funded grants. 
● 
Is configurable to the NBRC’s requirements and specifications, including workflows for items such as application receipt and review, Letter of Interest receipt, review, and approval, by internal NBRC staff members and external reviewer-stakeholders. 
● 
Includes a public-facing portal which allows grantees to view grant opportunities, submit applications, monitor status of grants, and submit reports. 
● 
Is a cloud-hosted SaaS application that has a Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) Moderate authorization or be able to achieve an Authority to Operate (ATO) as per the FISMA and NIST compliance standards in time for the NBRC to begin test modes and practical operational training. The NBRC's timeline corresponds to application acceptance for the next anticipated grant round, October 1, 2023. 
● 
Is able to integrate with the NBRC’s financial services provider, PFS, running a Momentum-based system, in order to facilitate disbursements, payments, invoices, vendor files and funding obligation; currently the application portal does not integrate with any other systems. 
● 
Ensures ease of integration with the NBRC’s current technology infrastructure, such that common file types – created by Adobe, MS Office Suite, and common image formats such as JPG & PNG – are compatible for upload/download and electronic signatures. 
● 
Can be configured and provide ‘Dashboard’ functionality to support internal and external users. 
● 
Will provide and configure ‘Notifications’ and alerts within the system and through email integration. 
● 
Ensures data and document integrity and becomes the repository for all NRBC proposal and grant materials. 
● 
Provides the ability for future integration and migration of the NRBC SaaS data to other systems by providing the means to download all data from the SaaS application in compatible comma-separated values (CSV) format. 
● 
Meets Section 508 accessibility requirements. 
● 
Grantees submit project performance reports on a quarterly basis, some additional reporting based on type of project potentially yearly for financial and property reports. Reports are submitted using federal standard forms. These reports are NOT part of the application. 
● 
Will utilize electronic signature tools Adobe Sign and/or BOX Sign

subsections.title: C.5.1 APPLICATION
subsections.content:
● 
A simple Graphical User Interface (GUI) that allows grant applicants to complete and submit a NBRC grant application online, via fillable fields (up to 70 fields). 
○ 
Applicants must be able to upload supplemental documents in the form of PDFs, MS Office Suite, and photos (e.g., JPEG, PNG, etc.). For example, a SF424cbw, or SF270. Also, NBRC-generated forms. There are approximately 50 forms that comprise the entirety of the NBRC’s grant making process, from application through project close-out. 
○ 
Applicants must be able to input information such as name, organization, contact information, project description, etc. in a text box. NBRC will provide field names & response length maximums (e.g., max of 300 words). 
● 
Capability for NBRC staff to access the submitted applications and download documents therein. 
● 
Capability for NBRC-approved stakeholders to access submitted applications and download documents therein. 
● 
NBRC staff should be able to comment on applications in a format that is not visible to the applicant (e.g., the “checklist” in the current database). 
● 
NBRC staff should be able to communicate with grantees (and vice-versa) within the system.

subsections.title: C.5.2 FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT
subsections.content:
● 
Funding Inflow & Outflow: 
○ 
Source of funds (Agency, other Federal, non-Federal) 
○ 
Use of funds (Personnel, Indirect, Equipment, Construction, etc.) 
● 
Overall project funding status: 
○ 
Amount of funds obligated, spent to-date, amount remaining, matching funds expended, etc. 
● 
Payment processing & tracking: 
○ 
Status of outstanding/pending reimbursements 
○ 
Verification of payment processing (NBRC and grantee) 
○ 
The vendor will not need to perform any financial transactions

subsections.title: C.5.3 GMS SERVICE DESK SUPPORT
subsections.content:
Service Desk Support is a required task following implementation. 
The vendor shall provide a 3-tier, ITIL-based Service Desk for incidents and service requests for the GMS application. Incidents and service requests will be classified by impact and urgency to determine priority for resolution. The vendor is required to provide GMS Service Desk support during implementation and data migration phases. Following GMS application implementation, Tier 1, 2, and 3 Service Desk support tiers are each provided as required tasks. 
Support at all tiers is provided daily in English, at minimum 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Eastern time, excluding weekends and Federal holidays. 
The vendor is responsible for providing and maintaining their own ticketing and call system. 
Tier 1 Service Desk Support: The Tier 1 Service Desk shall support incoming incidents and service requests from electronic mail, telephone, and as forwarded from the OIT Service Desk and National Service Hotline. The goal of Tier 1 support is First Contact Resolution (FCR). Tier 1 is the front end for NBRC GMS customers (grant applicants and NBRC-designated stakeholder-users) to obtain help using the GMS application, reporting service incidents, or placing service requests. 
Tier 2 Service Desk Support: Tier 2 support serves as an escalation point for incidents and service requests that cannot be readily resolved by Tier 1 at first contact. Tier 2 assesses incidents and services requests, clarifies data with end users and is responsible for complex incident and service request resolution. Tier 2 interfaces with OIT staff if necessary and escalates critical issues to Tier 3 if they are unable to provide resolution. 
Tier 3 Service Desk Support: vendor shall provide Tier 3 Service Desk support, the highest level of subject matter expertise, in support of the GMS application and environments. Tier 3 is the final escalation point for all incidents and service requests. Tier 3 is responsible for advanced troubleshooting, coordinating root cause analysis of incidents, reporting product and data defects, coordinating required code changes, and resolving any incident or service request.

subsections.title: C.5.4 TRAINING
subsections.content:
The vendor shall provide training to NBRC personnel on using the cloud based grant management database. The vendor shall provide a staff training guide and grant applicant instructions. Grant applicant instructions must be user-friendly, defined here as being accessible to a member of the public with a limited technical capacity that does not extend beyond the basic Microsoft Office suite (Word, Outlook, PPT, and Excel). 
Additional training specifications are as follows: 
• 
Government’s expectation is that training will comprise between 2 and 4 8-hour days, where approximately 50-75% of time is spent training NBRC staff on features utilized for grant management and receiving and processing grant applications, and the remaining time is spent training NBRC staff on the grantee side of the product (i.e., from the perspective of a grantee, how he/she would engage with the product to, for example, submit a grant application or a reimbursement request). 
• 
Government expects that training will occur in a virtual environment (via MS Teams, Zoom, or Google Meet), and will occur within 90 days of contract. 
• 
Government expects that multi-day training – consistent with bullet #1 of this section – will occur during base year, but that up to 1 full day of training will be provided in subsequent contract years to update NBRC staff on new features and product updates. 
These trainings will also occur in a virtual environment consistent with bullet #2 of this section.

subsections.title: C.5.5 CONTINUITY OF OPERATIONS
subsections.content: The vendor shall be responsible for meeting all availability SLAs and maintaining the GMS SaaS application’s continuity of operations in the event of critical failures. The vendor’s quote will indicate how they will be able to sustain operations of all environments in the event of critical failures. Critical failures include, but are not limited to, system interface outages, network outages, Cloud Service Provider failures, vendor’s Internet Service Provider failures, database failures, application failures, Denial of Service attacks, or SaaS damage from malware. The GMS SaaS system Recovery Point Objective is the last valid transaction. The GMS SaaS Recovery Time Objective is the outage time permitted by the monthly 95% availability.

subsections.title: C.5.6 COORDINATE A PROJECT KICK-OFF MEETING
subsections.content:
The contractor shall schedule, coordinate, and host a virtual Project Kick-Off Meeting (Section F, Deliverable 01). The meeting shall provide an introduction between the contractor personnel and Government personnel who will be involved with the TO. The meeting shall provide the opportunity to discuss technical, management, and security issues, and travel authorization and reporting procedures. At a minimum, the attendees shall include Key contractor Personnel, representatives from the directorates, NBRC, other relevant Government personnel, the GSA Contracting Officer’s Representative (COR), and the Contracting Officer (CO). The Kick-Off Meeting shall be held within ten business days of the Task Order Start Date. 
At least two business days prior to the Kick-Off Meeting, the contractor shall provide a Kick-Off Meeting Agenda (Section F, Deliverable 02). The agenda shall include, at a minimum, the following topics/deliverables: 
a. 
Points of Contact (POCs) for all parties. 
b. 
Personnel discussion (i.e., roles and responsibilities and lines of communication between contractor and Government). 
c. 
Transition-In Plan (draft) and discussion. 
d. 
Financial reporting and invoicing requirements. 
e. 
Quality Management Plan (QMP) (draft) 
The Government will provide the contractor with the number of Government participants for the Kick-Off Meeting, and the contractor shall provide digital copies of the presentation for all present. 
The contractor shall draft and provide a Kick-Off Meeting Minutes Report (Section F, Deliverable 03) documenting the Kick-Off Meeting discussion and capturing any action items at least two business days following the Kick-Off Meeting.

subsections.title: C.5.7 PREPARE A MONTHLY STATUS REPORT (MSR)
subsections.content:
The contractor shall develop and provide an MSR (Section F, Deliverable 04). The MSR is due by the 10th calendar day of the month (or next business day if the 10th is not a business day) and shall include the following: 
a. 
Activities during the reporting period, by task (include ongoing activities, new activities, and activities completed, and progress to date on all above mentioned activities). Each section shall start with a brief description of the task. 
b. 
Problems and corrective actions taken. Also include issues or concerns and proposed resolutions to address them. 
c. 
Personnel gains, losses, and status (security clearance, etc.). 
d. 
Government actions required. 
e. 
Schedule (show major tasks, milestones, and deliverables; planned and actual start and completion dates for each). 
f. 
Accumulated invoiced cost for each CLIN up to the previous month. 
g. 
Projected cost of each CLIN for the current month.

subsections.title: C.5.8 MONTHLY STATUS MEETINGS
subsections.content:
The CO, COR, and other Government personnel (as appropriate) will have a Monthly Status Meeting (Section F, Deliverable 05) by the 15th calendar day of the month (or next business day if the 15th is not a business day) in a virtual setting with the contractor to review the status of the project. At these meetings the Government will apprise the contractor of any concerns and the vendor will apprise the Government of any issues being experienced. Appropriate action shall be taken to resolve outstanding issues. The contractor shall draft and provide a Monthly Status Meeting Minutes (Section F, Deliverable 06) documenting the Monthly Status Meeting discussion and capturing any action items at least five business days following the Monthly Status Meeting. 
In addition, the contractor agrees to attend any additional post award meetings convened by the contracting activity in accordance with Federal Acquisition Regulation Subpart 42.5. These meetings shall be at no additional cost to the government.

subsections.title: C.5.9 PROVIDE QUALITY MANAGEMENT
subsections.content: The contractor shall identify and implement its approach for providing and ensuring quality throughout its solution to meet the requirements of the TO. The contractor shall provide a draft QMP by the Kick-Off Meeting with a final QMP due within 10 business days of the Kick-Off Meeting, and shall maintain and update it as changes in the program processes are identified (Section F, Deliverable 07). The contractor’s QMP shall describe the application of the appropriate methodology (i.e., quality control and/or quality assurance) for accomplishing TO performance expectations and objectives. The QMP shall describe how the appropriate methodology integrates with the Government’s requirements.

subsections.title: C.5.10 QUALITY ASSURANCE
subsections.content: The government shall evaluate the vendor’s performance under this contract in accordance with the Quality Assurance Surveillance Plan (QASP). This plan is primarily focused on what the Government must do to ensure that the vendor has performed in accordance with the performance standards identified below. It defines how the performance standards will be applied, the frequency of surveillance, and the minimum acceptable defect rate(s). The QASP will be provided to the contractor as a courtesy but the Government reserves the right to make changes/revisions at any time.

subsections.title: C.5.11 TRANSITION-IN
subsections.content: The contractor shall provide a draft Transition-In Plan by the Kick-Off Meeting with a final Transition-In Plan due within 10 business days of the Kick-Off Meeting (Section F, Deliverable 08). The contractor shall ensure that there will be minimum service disruption to vital Government business and no service degradation during and after transition. The transition shall be completed within 90 days of award if the quoted SaaS is fully FedRAMP authorized, or within 60 days after issuance of an ATO.

subsections.title: C.6.1 RECOGNIZED HOLIDAYS
subsections.content:
Federal law (5 U.S.C. 6103) establishes the public holidays for federal employees. Please note that most federal employees work on a Monday through Friday schedule. For these employees, when a holiday falls on a non-workday – Saturday or Sunday – the holiday usually is observed on Monday (if the holiday falls on Sunday) or Friday (if the holiday falls on Saturday). Contractors shall follow these same guidelines. Direct billing/invoicing shall not be allowed for any federal government holidays. Federal holidays are listed at the Office of Personnel and Management at https://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/pay-leave/federal-holidays/. The current list of Federal holidays includes: 
New Year’s Day 
Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr. 
Washington’s Birthday 
Memorial Day 
Juneteenth National Independence Day 
Independence Day 
Labor Day 
Columbus Day 
Veterans Day 
Thanksgiving Day 
Christmas Day

subsections.title: C.6.2 APPLICABLE PUBLICATIONS
subsections.content:
The vendor must abide by all applicable regulations, publications, manuals, and local policies and procedures. 
The vendor's proposed solution shall be in accordance with the solicitation requirements and consistent with the most current version of all the applicable documents identified below at time 
of quote submission. GSA believes sufficient information has been provided via this solicitation to ensure the vendor’s proposed solution is consistent with all applicable laws, regulations, policies, and procedures at time of quote submission. However, should at any time during performance it becomes known to the vendor that a more up to date version of X policy and X policy changes and the proposed solution is no longer consistent with those policies/laws the Vendor will notify the COR and GSA CO in writing with a proposed solution that meets the requirements of both policies/laws. Changes in policies/laws that substantially change the software itself shall be negotiated via a modification at the applicable time. However, if the policies/laws do not require substantial changes to the software, the contractor shall ensure the software follows the new policies/laws without a change in price.

subsections.title: D.1 PRESERVATION, PACKAGING, PACKING, AND MARKING
subsections.content: Preservation, packaging, packing, and marking of all deliverables must conform to normal commercial packing standards to assure safe delivery at destination.

subsections.title: D.2 SOFTWARE AND MAGNETIC MEDIA MARKING
subsections.content:
Packages containing software or other magnetic media shall be marked in accordance with requirements set forth in the task order, or if none is specified, shall be marked on external containers with a notice reading substantially as follows: “CAUTION: SOFTWARE/MAGNETIC MEDIA ENCLOSED. DO NOT EXPOSE TO HEAT OR MAGNETIC FIELDS.” 
Task Order Request 47QFAA23Q0005 
PAGE D-1

subsections.title: E.1 PLACE OF INSPECTION AND ACCEPTANCE
subsections.content: Inspection and acceptance of all work performance, reports, and other deliverables under this TO will be performed by authorized representatives of GSA in coordination with the COR. Final acceptance of all work performance, reports, and other deliverables under this order shall be performed by the COR with coordination with the CO.

subsections.title: E.2 SCOPE OF INSPECTION
subsections.content:
All deliverables will be inspected for content, completeness, accuracy, and conformance to TO requirements by authorized representatives of GSA in coordination with the COR. Inspection may include validation of information or software through the use of automated tools, testing, or inspections of the deliverables, as specified in the TO. The scope and nature of this inspection will be sufficiently comprehensive to ensure the completeness, quality, and adequacy of all deliverables. 
The Government requires a period NTE 15 workdays after receipt of deliverable items for inspection and acceptance or rejection.

subsections.title: E.3 BASIS OF ACCEPTANCE
subsections.content:
The basis for acceptance shall be compliance with the requirements set forth in the TO and relevant terms and conditions of the MAS contract. Deliverable items rejected shall be corrected in accordance with the applicable clauses. 
Acceptance will occur when all discrepancies, errors, or other deficiencies identified in writing by the Government have been resolved, through documentation updates, program correction, or other mutually agreeable methods. 
Reports, documents, and narrative-type deliverables will be accepted when all discrepancies, errors, or other deficiencies identified in writing by the Government have been corrected. If the deliverable is adequate, the Government may accept it or provide comments for incorporation. 
All of the Government’s comments on deliverables shall either be incorporated in the succeeding version of the deliverable, or the contractor shall explain to the Government’s satisfaction why such comments should not be incorporated. 
If the Government finds that a deliverable contains spelling errors, grammatical errors, or improper format, or otherwise does not conform to the quality assurance requirements stated within this TO, the document may be rejected without further review and returned to the contractor for correction and resubmission. If the contractor requires additional Government guidance to produce an acceptable version, the contractor shall arrange a meeting with the COR and CO.

subsections.title: E.4 WRITTEN ACCEPTANCE/REJECTION BY THE GOVERNMENT
subsections.content: The CO and/or COR will provide written notification of acceptance or rejection of all deliverables. All notifications of rejection will be accompanied with an explanation of the specific deficiencies causing the rejection.

subsections.title: F.1 PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE
subsections.content:
The anticipated period of performance shall consist of one 12-month Base Period beginning at the time of award with four 12-month Option Periods, as follows:
Base Year: Award for 12 months beginning in FY 23
0 Option Period 1: Months 13-24
1 Option Period 2: Months 25-36
2 Option Period 3: Months 37-48
3 Option Period 4: Months 49-60

subsections.title: F.2 PLACE OF PERFORMANCE
subsections.content: The place of performance will be at the vendor’s facility. Teleworking is at the discretion of the vendor as long as all employees are in the Continental United States (CONUS) or Hawaii and Alaska (OCONUS). At present, Microsoft Teams and Zoom are the collaborative VTC/Desktop/Application sharing tools used when engaging with NBRC staff. All work will be performed within the Continental United States (CONUS) plus Hawaii and Alaska (OCONUS).

subsections.title: F.3 HOURS OF OPERATION
subsections.content: The vendor is responsible for maintaining Grants Management Software availability 24 hours / day, 7 days / week to accommodate after-hours submissions by grantees. Technical support should also be available continuously, on the same schedule. Patching and upgrades must occur between the hours of 6 p.m. EST through 7 a.m. EST or on weekends or holidays.

subsections.title: F.4 TASK ORDER (TO) SCHEDULE AND MILESTONE DATES
subsections.content:
The following schedule of milestones will be used by the COR to monitor timely progress under this TO. The following abbreviations are used in this schedule: DEL: Deliverable IAW: In Accordance With NLT: No Later Than Deliverables are due the next business day if the due date falls on a holiday or weekend. Data Rights Clause -Abbreviations in the Gov’t Rights column of the table below shall be interpreted as follows: UR: Unlimited Rights, per FAR 27.404-1(a) and 52.227-14 RS: Restricted Software, per FAR 27.404-2 and 52.227-14 LD: Limited Rights Data, per FAR 27.404-2 and 52.227-14 For software or documents that may be either proprietary or open-source Commercial Off-the-Shelf (COTS), RS/LD rights apply to proprietary COTS software or documents and UR rights apply to open-source software or documents. The Government asserts UR rights to open source COTS software. Any collateral agreements (within the meaning of FAR) proposed for data, regardless of the type of rights offered, shall be subject to the requirements of TOR Section H.9. For purposes of the foregoing, the terms “collateral agreement,” “Supplier Agreement,” and “Commercial Supplier Agreement” have the same meaning. The Government does not assert any rights to management software tools if the contractor does not plan to charge the Government directly for that tool and does not propose that the Government will own or use that tool. The contractor shall deliver the deliverables listed in the following table on the dates specified:
DEL. # MILESTONE/ DELIVERABLE TOR REFERENCE DATE OF COMPLETION/ DELIVERY GOV’T RIGHTS
0 1 Kick-Off Meeting C.5.6 Within 10 business days of TO Start Date N/A
1 2 Kick-Off Meeting Agenda C.5.6 NLT 2 business days prior to Kick-Off Meeting UR
2 3 Kick-Off Meeting Minutes Report C.5.6 NLT 2 business days following Kick-Off Meeting UR
3 4 Monthly Status Report C.5.7 Monthly by the 10th calendar day of the month (or next business day if 10th is not a business day) UR
4 5 Monthly Status Meeting C.5.8 Monthly by the 15th calendar day of the month (or next business day if 15th is not a business day) N/A
5 6 Monthly Status Meeting Minutes C.5.8 NLT 2 business days following Monthly Status Meeting UR
6 7 Quality Management Plan (QMP) C.5.9 Draft due at Kick-Off Meeting w/ Final due within 10 business days of Kick-Off Meeting; updated as changes in program processes are identified UR
7 8 Transition-In Plan C.5.11 Draft due at Kick-Off Meeting w/ Final due within 10 UR
Unnamed: 0 business days of Kick-Off Meeting
All written Deliverables in above table shall be submitted via the ASSIST Collaborations Tool, with the “Type” selected to be “Report”. A courtesy copy shall also be emailed to the CO.

subsections.title: F.5 DELIVERABLES MEDIA
subsections.content:
The following are the required electronic formats, whose versions must be compatible with the latest, commonly available version on the market.
● Text Microsoft (MS) Word, Google Docs, PDF
0 ● Spreadsheets MS Excel, Google Sheets
1 ● Briefings MS PowerPoint, Google Slides
2 ● Drawings MS Visio, Google Drawings
3 ● Schedules MS Project, Smartsheet

subsections.title: F.6 PLACE(S) OF DELIVERY
subsections.content: As stated above, all written Deliverables in the above table shall be submitted via the ASSIST Collaborations Tool, with the “Type” selected to be “Report”. A courtesy copy shall also be emailed to the CO.

subsections.title: F.7 NOTICE REGARDING DELAY IN SERVICE
subsections.content: The contractor shall notify the CO and COR as soon as it becomes apparent to the contractor that a scheduled delivery will be late. The contractor shall provide the rationale for late delivery, the expected date for the delivery, and the project impact of the late delivery. The CO and COR will review the new schedule and provide guidance to the contractor. Such notification in no way limits any Government contractual rights or remedies including, but not limited to, termination.

subsections.title: G.1 CONTRACTING OFFICER’S REPRESENTATIVES (COR)
subsections.content:
The CO will appoint a Client COR and a GSA COR in writing through a COR Appointment Letter. The CORs will receive, for the Government, all work called for by the TO and will represent the CO in the technical phases of the work. The CORs will provide no supervisory or instructional assistance to contractor personnel. 
The CORs are not authorized to change any of the terms and conditions, scope, schedule, and price of the Contract or the TO. Changes in the scope of work will be made only by the CO by properly executed modifications to the Contract or the TO.

subsections.title: G.1.1 CONTRACT ADMINISTRATION
subsections.content:
Contracting Officer (CO): 
Steven Wright, Senior Contracting Officer 
Office of Contract Operations (CONOPS) 
Office of Professional Services and Human Capital Categories (PSHC) 
Federal Acquisition Service (FAS) 
General Services Administration (GSA) 
Client Contracting Officer’s Representative (COR) 
Identified upon award via correspondence from the CO 
GSA Contracting Officer’s Representative (COR) 
Identified upon award via correspondence from the CO

subsections.title: G.2 INVOICE SUBMISSION
subsections.content:
The contractor shall submit invoices not more than monthly. Each invoice shall contain all pricing components in sufficient detail necessary to reconcile charges invoiced. The contractor shall ensure that all charges, credits, and debits are shown on the invoice and that no additional data is required by GSA to verify the price of a service and verify the amount of discounts, credits or debits. 
The client agency will accept and certify services by signing the Acceptance Document generated by the contractor. This Acceptance Document must list all written deliverables (as shown in the table in Section F above) that were submitted to the Government in the listed service period. The Acceptance Document is attached in GSA ASSIST to the invoice (along with any other supporting documentation for the invoice). Electronic acceptance of the invoice in ASSIST by the CORs are considered concurrence and acceptance of services. 
The invoice shall be submitted via the GSA ASSIST system for evaluation and payment. Failure to submit through GSA ASSIST shall result in rejection of the invoice. 
The following information is required for all invoices: 
a. 
Invoice date 
b. 
Invoice number (contractor-generated) 
c. 
Task Order (PIID) number (provided by GSA) 
d. 
Contract number (contractor MAS contract number) 
e. 
Contractor Name 
f. 
Physical remittance address 
g. 
Point of Contact and phone number 
h. 
Invoice amount (per CLIN and Total) 
i. 
Total Billed to Date for current Period of Performance (POP) (per CLIN and Total) 
i. 
Service period (dates of service) 
j. 
Current POP dates (Base Period, Option Period One, etc.) 
k. 
Discount terms, if any

subsections.title: H.1 KEY PERSONNEL
subsections.content:
The following are the minimum personnel who shall be designated as “Key.” The Government does not intend to dictate the composition of the ideal team to perform this TO. 
Project Manager (PM) 
The Government desires that Key Personnel be assigned for the duration of the TO.

subsections.title: H.1.1 PROJECT MANAGER (PM)
subsections.content: The contractor shall identify a Project Manager (PM) by name who shall provide management, direction, administration, quality assurance, and leadership of the execution of this TO.

subsections.title: H.1.2 KEY PERSONNEL SUBSTITUTION
subsections.content:
The contractor shall not replace any personnel designated as Key Personnel without the written concurrence of the GSA CO. This notification shall be no later than ten calendar days in advance of any proposed substitution and shall include justification specifying the qualifications and experiences of each named Key individual in sufficient detail to permit evaluation of the impact on TO performance. 
Substitute Key Personnel qualifications shall be equal to, or greater than, those of the Key Personnel substituted. If the GSA CO and the GSA COR determine that a proposed substitute Key Personnel is unacceptable, or that the reduction of effort would be so substantial as to impair the successful performance of the work under the TO, the contractor may be subject to termination per FAR 52.212-4 paragraphs (l) or (m).

subsections.title: H.2 GOVERNMENT-FURNISHED INFORMATION (GFI)
subsections.content: Data will be transferred to the vendor at the time of award and provided via CSV format.

subsections.title: H.3 SECURITY REQUIREMENTS
subsections.content: The vendor shall be responsible for safeguarding all government equipment, information and property that may be provided for vendor use. At the close of each work period, government facilities, equipment, and materials shall be secured.

subsections.title: H.3.1 INFORMATION ASSURANCE
subsections.content: The contractor may have access to sensitive (including privileged and confidential) data, information, and materials of the U.S. Government. These printed and electronic documents are for internal use only and remain the sole property of the U.S. Government. Some of these materials are protected by the Privacy Act of 1974 (AMENDED) and Title 38. Unauthorized disclosure of Privacy Act or Title 38 covered materials is a criminal offense.

subsections.title: H.3.2 CYBER-SUPPLY CHAIN RISK MANAGEMENT (C-SCRM)
H.4 ORGANIZATIONAL CONFLICT OF INTEREST (OCI)
subsections.content: If a contractor has performed, is currently performing work, or anticipates performing work that creates or represents an actual or potential OCI, the contractor shall immediately disclose this actual or potential OCI to the GSA CO in accordance with FAR Subpart 9.5. The nature of the OCI may involve the prime contractor, subcontractors of any tier, or teaming partners.

subsections.title: H.5 SECTION 508 COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS
subsections.content: Unless the Government invokes an exemption, all Electronic and Information Technology (EIT) products and services proposed shall fully comply with Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, per the 1998 Amendments, 29 U.S.C. 794d, and the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board’s Electronic and Information Technology Accessibility Standards at 36 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1194. The contractor shall identify all EIT products and services provided, identify the technical standards applicable to all products and services provided, and state the degree of compliance with the applicable standards. Additionally, the contractor must clearly indicate where the information pertaining to Section 508 compliance can be found (e.g., Vendor’s or other exact web page location). The contractor must ensure that the list is easily accessible by typical users beginning at time of award.

subsections.title: H.7 TRAVEL
subsections.content: All vendor activities will be conducted virtually, and thus no travel will be required.

subsections.title: H.8 PRESS/NEWS RELEASE
subsections.content: The contractor shall not make any press/news release pertaining to this procurement without prior Government approval and only in coordination with the GSA CO.

subsections.title: H.9 DATA RIGHTS
subsections.content: All GMS data and all documents/materials produced under this contract shall remain the property of the Government. The vendor shall ensure that the government retains access and download capability of all data for research, investigation, transfer, or migration to other systems. All documents and materials produced under this contract shall be Government owned and are the property of the Government with all rights and privileges of ownership/copyright belonging exclusively to the Government. These documents and materials may not be used or sold by the vendor without written permission from the CO. All materials (not to include the software code) supplied to the Government shall be the sole property of the Government and may not be used for any other purpose. This right does not abrogate any other Government rights.

subsections.title: H.10 PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS SUMMARY (PRS)
subsections.content:
The PRS with acceptable quality levels is provided below.

subsections.title: I.1 TASK ORDER CLAUSES
subsections.content: All applicable and required FAR (as set forth in FAR 52.301) and GSAM clauses as provided in the contractor’s base MAS contract are hereby automatically flowed down to this task order, based on this specific task order type (e.g. FFP), PWS, competition requirements, and estimated dollar value.

subsections.title: I.2 FAR 52.252-2 CLAUSES INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE (FEB 1998)
subsections.content:
This contract incorporates one or more clauses by reference, with the same force and effect as if they were given in full text. Upon request, the Contracting Officer will make their full text available. Also, the full text of a clause may be accessed electronically at this/these address(es): 
(a) 
Federal Acquisition Regulation: https://www.acquisition.gov/far/ 
(b) 
General Services Acquisition Manual: https://www.acquisition.gov/GSAM/gsam.html 
(End of clause)

subsections.title: I.3 FAR CLAUSES INCORPORATED BY FULL TEXT
subsections.content:
FAR 52.217-8 OPTION TO EXTEND SERVICES (NOV 1999) 
The Government may require continued performance of any services within the limits and at the rates specified in the contract. These rates may be adjusted only as a result of revisions to prevailing labor rates provided by the Secretary of Labor. The option provision may be exercised more than once, but the total extension of performance hereunder shall not exceed 6 months. The Contracting Officer may exercise the option by written notice to the Contractor within 7 calendar days of the end of the current period of performance. 
(End of clause) 
FAR 52.217-9 OPTION TO EXTEND THE TERM OF THE CONTRACT (MAR 2000) 
a. 
The Government may extend the term of this contract by written notice to the Contractor within 7 calendar days of the end of the current period of performance; provided that the Government gives the Contractor a preliminary written notice of its intent to extend at least 30 calendar days before the contract expires. The preliminary notice does not commit the Government to an extension. 
b. 
If the Government exercises this option, the extended contract shall be considered to include this option clause. 
c. 
The total duration of this contract, including the exercise of any options under this clause, shall not exceed 5 years. 
(End of clause)

title: SECTION L -INSTRUCTIONS, CONDITIONS, AND NOTICES TO OFFERORS

subsections.title: L.1 FAR 52.252-1 SOLICITATION PROVISIONS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE (FEB 1998)
subsections.content:
This solicitation incorporates one or more solicitation provisions by reference, with the same force and effect as if they were given in full text. Upon request, the CO will make the full text available. The offeror is cautioned that the listed provisions may include blocks that must be completed by the offeror and submitted with its quotation or offer. In lieu of submitting the full text of those provisions, the offeror may identify the provision by paragraph identifier and provide the appropriate information with its quotation of offer. Also, the full text of a solicitation provision may be accessed electronically at this address: (a) Federal Acquisition Regulation: https://www.acquisition.gov/far/ (b) General Services Acquisition Manual: https://www.acquisition.gov/GSAM/gsam.html (c) Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement: https://www.acquisition.gov/dfars (End of provision)
FAR TITLE DATE
0 52.212-1 Instructions to Offerors -Commercial Products and Commercial Services Nov 2021
1 52.217-5 Evaluation of Options JUL 1990

subsections.title: L.2 GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
subsections.content:
a. 
The offeror is expected to examine this entire solicitation document including the Master/Basic Contract. Failure to do so will be at the offeror’s own risk. 
b. 
The Government may make an award based on initial offers received, without exchanges of such offers. Quotes shall set forth full, accurate, and complete information as required by this solicitation package (including Attachments listed in Section J). The penalty for making false statements in quotes is prescribed in 18 U.S.C. 1001. 
c. 
An offeror submitting restricted data shall mark it as follows in accordance with the FAR 52.215-1, Instructions to Offerors -Competitive Acquisition, which is incorporated by reference. FAR Clause 52.215-1(e) states: “Restriction on disclosure and use of data. Offerors that include in their quotes data that they do not want disclosed to the public for any purpose, or used by the Government except for evaluation purposes, shall – 
(1) 
Mark the title page with the following legend: 
This quote includes data that shall not be disclosed outside the Government and shall not be duplicated, used, or disclosed--in whole or in part--for any purpose other than to evaluate this quote. If, however, a contract is awarded to this offeror as a result of--or in connection with--the submission of this data, the Government shall have the right to duplicate, use, or disclose the data to the extent provided in the resulting contract. This restriction does not limit the Government’s right to use information contained in this data if it is obtained from another source without restriction. The data subject to this restriction are contained in sheets [insert numbers or other identification of sheets]; and 
(2) 
Mark each sheet of data it wishes to restrict with the following legend: Use or disclosure of data contained on this sheet is subject to the restriction on the title page of this quote.” 
d. 
The Government assumes no liability for disclosure or use of unmarked data and may use or disclose the data for any purpose. Unless restricted, information submitted in response to this request may become subject to disclosure to the public pursuant to the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. 552). 
e. 
This procurement is conducted under the procedures of FAR Subpart 16.5. The policies and procedures of FAR Subpart 15.3 do not apply.

subsections.title: L.3 GENERAL INFORMATION
subsections.content:
Quotes shall be valid for a period of 90 calendar days from close of the TOR. 
Offerors must be registered in ASSIST to receive an award. Please complete registration via this link: https://assist.gsa.gov/assist-web/registration/contractor/search

subsections.title: L.4 SUBMISSION OF QUESTIONS
subsections.content: The offeror may submit any questions grouped and referenced by the particular TOR section / subsection number directly to the CO via email at steven.wright@gsa.gov with an informational copy to the Contract Specialist (CS) at amanda.wesson@gsa.gov by 9:00 am PT (Pacific Time) on 03/15/2023. The government’s responses to submitted questions will be provided to all prospective offerors as an amendment to the solicitation. The government may consider any questions received after the stated question due date / time in the solicitation, although at its discretion, and reserves the right to not respond to questions received after the originally stated due date.

subsections.title: L.5 SUBMISSION OF OFFERS
subsections.content:
The offer shall be provided to the Government in two parts (each part in separate folders/files): Part I – Pricing, and Part II – Technical. Both parts are due and shall be submitted by the location, due date, and time indicated above. Offerors shall not include any pricing data in the Part II – Technical Quote. 
Offerors must be registered in GSA eBuy to submit a quote. Submissions shall be submitted in electronic format via GSA eBuy with an information copy sent to the CO and CS via email at steven.wright@gsa.gov and amanda.wesson@gsa.gov. 
*** THE DUE DATE OF THE QUOTE IS 9:00 AM PT (PACIFIC TIME) ON 
04/19/2023** 
No paper (hard copy) quote will be accepted. The quote shall NOT be submitted to any other parties. Any corrupt or unreadable documents shall not be considered for evaluation purposes. Any files not received by the cut-off date and time specified herein shall be deemed late and not considered for evaluation purposes. 
All electronic files shall be in Microsoft Word, Excel, or .pdf formats. Pages must maintain 1” margins, 12 point Times New Roman font or equal, single spaced and single sided. Unless otherwise specified, pages shall be 8.5”x11”. Charts / Graphics / Tables embedded in the quote 
will count toward any page limitations. Charts / Graphics / Tables text shall be a minimum of 9 point Times New Roman font, and 11”x17” foldouts may be used when providing tables and charts. 11”x17” foldouts will be counted as two pages where page limitations apply. Headers may be of a larger font. A Title Page, Table of Contents, Cover Letter, List of Figures, and Acronym List (if included) shall be submitted as separate pages within the main quote and are excluded from any maximum page counts. 
Any pages submitted beyond any specified page limitations will be removed and not evaluated.

subsections.title: L.5.1 PASS/FAIL CRITERIA QUOTE SUBMISSION
subsections.content:
For the purposes of evaluating the Pass/Fail Technical Quote Criteria as set forth in Section M.2, the offeror shall provide the following information under Part II. Failure to meet the requirements of any single Pass/Fail criterion will make the quote ineligible for award, with no further evaluation of the Technical and Cost/Price quote. The penalty for making false statements in quotes is prescribed in 18 U.S.C. 1001. 
Pass/Fail Criteria 
a. 
FedRAMP Authorization Status of Grants Management SaaS: The Grants Management SaaS shall be currently Moderate FedRAMP authorized OR currently going through the process of obtaining approval of the FedRAMP authorization with another agency. Any infrastructure or platform to be used to meet the requirements of this task order shall also be currently FedRAMP authorized OR currently going through the process of obtaining approval of the FedRAMP authorization with another agency. 
The offeror must submit clear and convincing evidence of FedRAMP authorization for the SaaS, as well as any infrastructure or platform to be used to meet the requirements of the task order. Please provide a screenshot of your FedRAMP SaaS in the FedRAMP marketplace as either “Approved” or “In Process”. 
However, if the SaaS is currently going through the FedRAMP authorization process with another agency, the offeror must submit a signed statement to this effect and include contact information for the Government Point of Contact (POC), including name, title, agency, phone number, and email address. The POC may be contacted to confirm the signed statement. The signed statement shall be included in this FedRAMP authorization Pass/Fail element. 
b. 
C-SCRM Questionnaire (Attachment C): The C-SCRM Questionnaire shall be completed and submitted with the quote. Failure to answer all questions will result in a Fail and the quote being ineligible for award. All yes/no questions must be answered in the affirmative to receive a Pass. Further C-SCRM details are in section H.3.2. 
c. 
Section 508 Compliance: The offeror’s written quote shall include a statement, provided at the time of quote submission, indicating its capability to comply with Section 508 requirements throughout its performance of this TO in compliance with Section H.5. 
d. 
MAS Contract -Latest Refresh: The offeror must have accepted Refresh 0015, dated 01/18/2023, for the associated MAS contract. Upon quote submission, the CO will review GSA eLibrary to confirm that Refresh 0015 has been accepted.
