subsections.title: L.6.1 PART I – PRICING
subsections.content:
The Pricing offer shall contain the following tabs: 
a. 
Solicitation/Contract/Order for Commercial Items (SF 1449) (TAB A). The form must be executed and signed by representatives of the offeror authorized to commit the offeror to contractual obligations. Completing and signing the form constitutes the offeror's acceptance of the terms and conditions of the proposed task order. 
b. 
Section B.3 – Services and Price Schedule (TAB B). The offeror shall indicate the price to be charged for each item in Section B.3. 
c. 
Pricing Table (TAB C). The offeror shall provide a completed Pricing Table in accordance with the Pricing Table template (Section J, Attachment D). The submission shall contain all labor categories (both key and non-key) that will be working on this effort in the Support Services CLINs (0001, 1001, 2001, 3001, and 4001), along with the level of effort proposed for each labor category, their base MAS contract hourly rates, discounts offered (if any), and task order hourly rates. For services being proposed under the Software Licensing CLINs (0002, 1002, 2002, 3002, and 4002) whereby the price of the service is already included in the software licensing, this table shall not include those applicable labor categories. 
d. 
Pricing Assumptions (TAB D). Offerors must submit under a separate tab, any assumptions, if applicable, upon which the Price Quote is based. 
e. 
Extension Statement under FAR 52.217-8 “Option to Extend Services” (TAB E). The offeror is not being requested to propose a specific price for the potential up to six-month extension provided for under FAR 52.217-8 “Option to Extend Services”, which is incorporated in Section I of the task order. The offeror shall indicate confirmation in its quote, if unilaterally exercised by the Government (for up to six months), that the unit monthly pricing as contained in Section B of the task order for the final option period will remain unchanged during this up to six-month extension period. 
f. 
Pricing Narrative (TAB F). The offeror shall provide a Pricing Narrative (not to exceed 3 pages) which describes the services that would be offered under the Support Services CLINs (0001, 1001, 2001, 3001, and 4001) as well as the services under the Software Licensing CLINs (0002, 1002, 2002, 3002, and 4002). The narrative shall differentiate the services being offered under each CLIN.

subsections.title: L.6.2 PART II – TECHNICAL
subsections.content:
The Technical offer shall contain the following tabs: 
a. 
Project Staffing Plan Table (TAB A). The offeror shall provide a completed Project Staffing Plan in accordance with the Project Staffing Plan Table template (Section J, Attachment E). The submission shall contain all labor categories (both key and non-key) that will be working on this effort in the Support Services CLINs (0001, 1001, 2001, 3001, and 4001). All Key Personnel proposed shall be named in the Project Staffing Plan Table and available to begin work immediately on the project start date. If the names of non-key personnel are not known prior to offer submission, the offeror may indicate “TBD” in the Project Staffing Plan Table. The names of non-key personnel are the only identifiers that may remain unspecified in the Project Staffing Plan Table. The names of all non-key personnel that can be provided should be provided. For services being proposed under the Software Licensing CLINs (0002, 1002, 2002, 3002, and 4002) whereby the service is already included in the software licensing, this table shall not include those applicable labor categories. 
The experiences, skills, and qualifications in the Project Staffing Plan Table proposed for each named key and non-key personnel shall conform to the actual experiences, skills, and qualifications. 
The offeror shall ensure there is consistency in Level of Effort between the Staffing Plans provided in Part II and the Price Quotes provided in Part I. 
b. 
Key Personnel Qualification Matrix (KPQM) and Letters of Commitment (TAB B). The offeror shall submit a completed Key Personnel Qualification Matrix (Section J, Attachment F) for each Key Person proposed, specifying the qualifications and experiences of each named Key individual. No resume is required to be submitted for Key Personnel with the offeror's quote. 
Each Key Personnel Qualification Matrix shall be limited to two pages per individual. Offerors may use 9-point font for the KPQM and may use landscape page orientation. 
The offeror shall also provide a one-page Letter of Commitment for each Key individual, stating the Key Person’s commitment and availability to perform work at the project start date, signed by each proposed Key Person at the quote submission due date. The Letter shall state that (1) the proposed Key Person named is employed by the prime offeror or has an offer of employment from the specified prime offeror that the Key Person intends to accept in the event of an award being made to the offeror and (2) the proposed Key Person is available and committed to begin work on the Project Start Date. The required Letters of Commitment are not included in the page count for the Key Personnel Qualification Matrix. 
c. 
Staffing Narrative (TAB C). The offeror shall provide a Staffing Narrative (not to exceed 5 pages) which describes the firm’s ability to provide the full range of required services (for both the Support Services CLINs and the Software Licensing CLINs) throughout the task order period with the staffing and personnel being proposed. The narrative shall detail the basis and rationale for the labor mix, labor categories, labor hours, and the proposed mix of key and non-key personnel. 
The narrative shall explain all services that are included in the Software Licensing CLINs and differentiate between those services and the services being provided via the Support Services CLINs. It must be clearly delineated to the Government what services are being provided under each of the two CLINs. Services already included with the Software Licensing CLINs must not be also included within the Support Services CLINs. 
The offeror shall describe its approach, for both key and non-key positions, to hiring, retaining, and replacing appropriately qualified personnel throughout the life of this task order; and its methodology for maintaining the technical expertise of all personnel. 
The offeror shall affirmatively state in its quote that any listed experiences, skills, and qualifications for any non-key positions/individuals (named or unnamed) in the Project Staffing Plan, will conform to those experiences, skills, and qualifications that it plans to provide and comply with when filling the applicable non-key positions. Failure to conform 
to the proposed experiences, skills, and qualifications during the hiring process will be considered in the Government’s assessment of contractual remedies it may decide to take after award. 
d. 
Technical Approach and Management / Quality Control (TAB D). The contractor shall submit a written narrative which shall not exceed 8 pages containing information on how the offeror will facilitate effective communication among all contractor, subcontractor (if applicable), and Government stakeholders. The contractor shall provide an explanation of how it will maintain management control of the project, including oversight of its own employees and/or any subcontractors. The contractor must also explain the methodologies used to maintain management and quality control. 
e. 
Relevant Corporate Experience (TAB E). 
For each relevant Corporate Experience reference, the offeror shall provide no more than a two (2) page narrative clearly articulating how and why it believes the referenced work is relevant (size, scope, and complexity) to the specific requirements (Grants Management SaaS) the contractor is proposing to accomplish within the requirements of the TOR. Each project must be recent, i.e. completed within the last three (3) years, or currently ongoing with at least one (1) year of the project completed. References not in accordance with these timeframes will not be evaluated. The Prime contractor must submit at least one (1), but no more than three (3), relevant and recent project experiences of their own. No more than a total of two (2) relevant and recent project experiences provided in response to the solicitation may be from subcontractors. [NOTE: the decision to work (or not work) with subcontractors does NOT remove the requirement that the prime contractor must have the GMS SaaS and all applicable labor categories used to support the requirements on their own (prime’s) MAS contract under one of the SINs listed in Section B.3 above.] A subcontractor’s relevant and recent project experience will only be evaluated IF the subcontractor also provides a Letter of Commitment, signed by a company executive on company letterhead, stating the firm is committed to be a subcontractor, at time of award, on this project for the prime contractor submitting the response to the solicitation. If the offeror is proposing a Contractor Team Arrangement (CTA), each prime contractor must submit at least one (1) relevant and recent project experiences of their own applicable to the requirements they would be responsible for meeting under this solicitation. The Government will not review any additional corporate experiences submitted in excess of the above stated limitations. 
Project experiences shall contain information for each project as follows: 
- 
Contractor Name/Project Name/Contract Number 
- 
Customer Point of Contact for project (phone number and email) (the Government reserves the right to contact references and/or project owners to obtain additional clarifying information regarding project relevance or contractor performance) 
- 
Project performance period (include months/years) 
- 
Dollar value of the entire project and dollar value of the part of the project relevant to the services being proposed to be performed by that contractor under this project. 
- 
Summary of the project including a clear description of the requirements, and results achieved and the methodology, tools, labor categories, and processes utilized in performing the work 
- 
Narrative clearly articulating how the referenced work is relevant to the specific role within the PWS the contractor is being proposed to be performing 
- 
Major deliverables produced that relate to the Section C requirements being specifically performed by the provided reference. 
Note: Master contract vehicles, such as GSA Schedules, Blanket Purchase Agreements, and Indefinite Delivery/Indefinite Quantity contracts will not be considered as relevant references, and will not be evaluated. Rather, only specific task orders issued under such vehicles should be submitted for evaluation. 
f. 
Technical Assumptions (TAB F). The contractor shall identify and address any assumptions affecting the technical quote citing the component(s) of the quote to which they pertain. All technical assumptions and basis of estimate assumptions shall be included in the technical volume. This shall include any non-price information that serves as the basis of a price assumption identified in the contractor’s price quote. The Government reserves the right to reject any quote that includes any assumption that adversely impacts the Government’s requirements. 
g. 
Demonstration of Software (TAB G). The offeror shall provide a demonstration of the proposed software, which shall be recorded and uploaded to YouTube.com via the link provided in Tab G. This video shall be available to the Government for no less than six months from the date that quotes are due (see Section L.5 above). (.MP4, .wmv, .avi and all other video files will not be accepted.) The video length shall not exceed 60 minutes. The video shall include a step-by-step demonstration of the main functions of the following: 
○ 
The reimbursement tab/screen; 
○ 
The interface that tracks application completeness; 
○ 
The dashboards for reporting on different program spending/grantmaking totals; 
○ 
The interface where a grantee would submit documents or application information; 
○ 
The visual of how communications happen within the system. 
○ 
How to develop a grant application (from Government/NBRC’s perspective) 
The video demonstration of the software will be used to assess the offeror’s capability to satisfy the requirements set forth in the TOR. Following the demonstration of the software, the Government may -but is not required to-submit written questions to the offeror, as deemed prudent, to clarify the offeror’s proposed capabilities, methodologies, and approaches. The Government intends to ask clarifying questions as may be useful for the evaluators to sufficiently understand what is being proposed. 
The offeror shall restrict the privacy settings for the demonstration video at YouTube.com. The privacy setting shall be Private (not Public or Unlisted) with access provided only to the Contracting Officer and the Contract Specialist (email addresses listed in Section L.5 above). It is the responsibility of the offeror to ensure the privacy of the video. The Government may request that the contractor add additional email addresses after the solicitation closes. If additional email addresses are requested, the offeror shall provide access within two (2) business days 
h. 
All Pass / Fail Items (TAB H): All pass / fail criteria from section L.5.1 shall be included in Tab H.

subsections.title: L.7 IN-DEPTH FEEDBACK THROUGH OPEN REPORTING METHODS (INFORM)
A. Overview of the IN-depth Feedback through Open Reporting Methods (INFORM) Process
subsections.content:
This solicitation is part of GSA’s post award communication process called INFORM. The process is designed to enhance the quality and usefulness of post-award communications by providing greater transparency and openness into the procurement process. INFORM seeks to increase GSA-industry communication by providing clearer and more complete information to explain the award decision. 
Through the INFORM process, GSA will seek to share additional information with offerors in writing and/or through an oral feedback meeting1 that is not required by statute or regulation. For purposes of this solicitation, and in addition to any information required by FAR Part 8.405-2(d), GSA is providing each offeror with the opportunity to participate in the INFORM process as further discussed below. The additional opportunities set forth in this section do NOT constitute a debriefing or required 
debriefing pursuant to FAR 15.506. This is a procurement being conducted pursuant to FAR Part 8 and, accordingly, any regulatory notification of award and a brief explanation of the basis for the award decision are specified at FAR 8.405-2(d). 
1 The oral feedback meeting may be held in person or via an electronic means.

subsections.title: B. Detailed Description of the INFORM Process
B.1. Component 1 -Notification of Award
subsections.content:
After award and in accordance with any post-award notification timeframes required by regulation (i.e., FAR Part 8.405-2), the contracting officer will issue written notices to the successful and unsuccessful offerors (the Notification Letter and Evaluation Statement (NLES)). The notices will contain: 
● 
All information required by statute or regulation; 
● 
An unredacted copy of the complete technical evaluation for that particular offeror that includes a full description of the unsuccessful offeror’s strengths, weaknesses, risks, and deficiencies; 
● 
An overall technical evaluation summary for that particular offeror and the successful offeror that includes evaluated price; overall technical ranking, rating, or score.

subsections.title: B.2. Component 2 -Request for Oral Feedback Meeting or Written Questions
subsections.content:
Within three business days after receipt of the NLES, an offeror may, but is not required to: 
● 
Submit a written request to the contracting officer for an oral feedback meeting; 
● 
Submit a list of written questions to the contracting officer; or, 
● 
Take no further action. 
If an offeror does not request an oral feedback meeting or submit a list of written questions within the three day time period, the INFORM process is concluded. 
If the offeror submits a list of written questions in lieu of the oral feedback meeting, the contracting officer will attempt to respond within five business days of receipt of the written questions. Unless otherwise stated, the contracting officer’s response to the written questions will conclude the INFORM process. 
If the offeror requests an oral feedback meeting, the offeror should provide the following information: 
● 
Primary point of contact; 
● 
List of participants with titles (e.g., Senior Vice President); 
● 
List of topics to assist GSA better prepare for the oral feedback meeting; and, 
● 
Preference for in-person, telephone, or web-based conferencing (if available). 
The contracting officer will make every effort to schedule the oral feedback meeting within five business days of the offeror’s receipt of the notification of award.

subsections.title: B.3. Component 3 -Oral Feedback Meeting
subsections.content:
During the oral feedback meeting, GSA’s objectives are to provide: 
● 
Reasonable responses to written questions submitted by the offeror; 
● 
Cohesive explanations for the evaluation conclusions and contract award decisions; 
● 
Any additional information about the fairness and impartiality of the evaluation and whether the award decision was rational; 
● 
Reasonable responses to additional questions raised during the meeting; 
● 
Additional transparency into the underlying competition process; and, 
● 
A greater understanding of the evaluation and award process. 
GSA will not provide any information that is prohibited by law or regulation.

subsections.title: B.4. Component 4 -Post Oral Feedback Meeting Questions
subsections.content:
Within two business days after the conclusion of the oral feedback meeting, the offeror may submit a list of written questions to the contracting officer. The contracting officer will provide a written response within five business days and, unless otherwise noted, the INFORM process is concluded. 
If the offeror elects not to submit a list of written questions within two business days after the oral feedback meeting, the INFORM process is concluded.

title: SECTION M – EVALUATION FACTORS FOR AWARD

subsections.title: M.1 METHOD OF AWARD
subsections.content:
A TO will be awarded to the offeror whose quote is the most advantageous to the Government, price and other factors considered. The four pass/fail elements listed in section L.5.1 will be evaluated first. Technical quotes that are in compliance with the pass/fail elements will then be evaluated based on the following factors: 1) Demonstration of Software, 2) Technical Approach and Quality Control, and 3) Relevant Corporate Experience. Factors 1, 2, and 3 are listed in order of importance, with Factor 1 considered to be the most important and Factor 3 considered to be the least important. 
All evaluation factors other than cost or price, when combined, are significantly more important than cost. Award may be made to other than the lowest price technically acceptable quote. 
This acquisition is being conducted under FAR 8.4. Principles and procedures of Subpart 15.3 do not apply. Accordingly, the Government may: 
a. 
Award on initial quotes, without exchanges. 
b. 
Ask clarification questions. Government may have communications with some—, but not all—, offerors, or about some—but not all—quote sections. The Government may ask questions and receive responses without allowing quote revisions. 
c. 
Engage in exchanges with offerors regarding some aspects of the price and/or technical package. The Government may request proposal revisions in accordance with the exchanges. The Government may waive informalities and minor irregularities in offers received. 
d. 
After an offeror has been selected for an award based upon the comparative evaluation, the Government may negotiate a final reduced price. 
Quotes shall set forth full, accurate, and complete information as required by this solicitation package (including Attachments). The penalty for making false statements in quotes is prescribed in 18 U.S.C. 1001.

subsections.title: M.2 PASS/FAIL ELEMENTS
subsections.content: The Government will evaluate the pass/fail elements as stated in Section L.5.1 above. A failure on any single Pass/Fail criteria will make the quote ineligible for award, with no further evaluation of the technical and cost quote conducted by the Government.

subsections.title: M.3 TECHNICAL EVALUATION FACTORS 1, 2 AND 3
subsections.content:
The technical package will be evaluated using comparative evaluation. This will be conducted by comparing quotes to each other (comparative analysis) and selecting the contractor that is best suited and provides the best value, considering the evaluation factors in this solicitation. The following evaluation factors in the table are listed in descending order of importance.
Evaluation Factor Description How Factors Will Be Evaluated
0 Evaluation Factor 1 Demonstration of Software -Video is accessible and in correct format -Video includes all functions listed above in Section L.6.2(g)
1 NaN NaN -Software user friendliness -Software functionality and applicability to NBRC requirements
2 Evaluation Factor 2 Technical Approach and Quality Control -Sufficiently demonstrates the offeror’s ability to effectively and efficiently perform all requirements and tasks -All elements listed above in Section L.6.2(a)(b)(c)(d) and (f) have been sufficiently addressed
3 Evaluation Factor 3 Relevant Corporate Experience -Projects are relevant (size, scope, and complexity) to Grants Management software requirements -Projects are recent (current or completed within last three years) -All elements of Section L.6.2(e) have been sufficiently addressed

subsections.title: M.4 COST/PRICE QUOTE EVALUATION
subsections.content:
The offeror’s cost quote (Section L.6.1 above) will be evaluated to determine the price as fair and reasonable. The six-month extension period, authorized by FAR clause 52.217-8, will not be included in the total evaluated cost; however, it will be evaluated to ensure that the option is available for the unilateral exercise of the Government should an extension become necessary. The offeror shall not propose a separate price for the six-month extension. 
Price will be evaluated as to fair and reasonableness. The Government will take into consideration any unbalanced pricing. An overall price that is excessively high (without sufficient justification) may be considered unreasonable and may receive no further consideration. The Government intends to issue an award without engaging in exchanges. Consequently, the contractor is highly encouraged to provide their best offer with the initial submission. However, the Government reserves the right to hold exchanges if it is determined advantageous to the Government to do so. This statement is not to be construed to mean that the Government is obligated to conduct such conversation with the contractor.

subsections.title: M.5 TECHNICAL ASSUMPTIONS
subsections.content:
Offeror assumptions will be reviewed in the context of the technical factor to which they apply. The Government reserves the right to reject any quote that includes any assumption that may adversely impact satisfying the Government’s requirements. 
Disclosure and awareness of any current, past, or known imminent future projects that would result in an organizational conflict of interest as identified in FAR Subpart 9.5 (If an actual or potential organizational conflict of interest is believed to exist, a mitigation plan in accordance with FAR Subpart 9.5 shall be submitted for government review and approval.)
